block.p: September

* ''ALMOST FAMOUS'' The director Cameron Crowe's first film since ''Jerry Maguire'' is the semiautobiographical story, set in 1973, of his days as a fledgling rock journalist. Against the wishes of his stern mother (Frances McDormand), the chipper, downy-cheeked hero (Patrick Fugit, a newcomer) goes on the road with Stillwater, a fictional Detroit rock band, to chronicle its drug trips and internal power struggles for Rolling Stone. Kate Hudson is an incandescent groupie named Penny Lane, and Billy Crudup plays Stillwater's charismatic guitarist. Compared with Oliver Stone's frenzied Dionysian visions of the rock world, Mr. Crowe's 70's rock memories may be tender, rose-colored and unabashedly nostalgic. Opens Wednesday. A related article is on Page 70.
''PARAGRAPH 175'' Rupert Everett narrates this documentary, by the creators of ''The Celluloid Closet,'' about the Nazi persecution of homosexuals. Wednesday.
''BAIT'' Jamie Foxx (fresh from his triumph in ''Any Given Sunday'') returns to the lighter side in this action comedy. Friday.

''CRIME AND PUNISHMENT IN SUBURBIA'' Dostoyevsky updated. Starring Monica Keena as a high school beauty whose world falls apart and Vincent Kartheiser as a distant admirer who becomes her guardian angel. With Ellen Barkin, Michael Ironside and Jeffrey Wright. Friday.
''DUETS'' A road trip comedy about six strangers with a passion for karaoke. Directed by Bruce Paltrow and featuring his daughter, Gwyneth, as an innocent Las Vegas showgirl. Friday.
''GOYA IN BORDEAUX'' Carlos Saura's surreal biography of the great Spanish artist features re-enactments of some of his ''Horrors of War'' works. Friday.

''HUMAN RESOURCES'' This French film examines the disillusionment of an idealistic young manager who becomes a boss in his father's factory and learns the bitterest personal lessons about class struggle and the relationship of management to labor. A high point of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Friday.

''INTO THE ARMS OF STRANGER''S This documentary, narrated by Judi Dench, looks back at the Kindertransport, in which 10,000 Jewish children from Germany, Austria and Czechoslovakia were saved from the Holocaust. Friday.
''LUMINARIAS'' The comedy about the romantic adventures of four Latina businesswomen stars Evelina Fernandez, Scott Bakula, Cheech Marin and Liz Torres. Friday.

''ON THE RUN'' When a travel agent reunites with a childhood friend who has just escaped from prison, his life turns into a nightmare. With Michael Imperioli and John Ventimiglia. Directed by Bruno de Almeida. Friday.

NEW YORK FILM FESTIVAL Sept. 22 - Oct. 9. The 38th annual festival presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center opens with Lars von Trier's ''Dancer in the Dark,'' which begins its commercial run on Sept. 23, and closes with Ang Lee's ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,'' which will open in December. ''Pollock,'' Ed Harris's biography of Jackson Pollock, is the official centerpiece. This year's festival has an unusual number of selections by Asian filmmakers, including (in addition to ''Crouching Tiger'') Takeshi Kitano's ''Brother'' (Japan), Im Kwon-Taek's ''Chunhyang'' (South Korea), Shinji Aoyama's ''Eureka'' (Japan), Nagisa Oshima's ''Gohatto'' (Japan), Wong Kar-wai's ''In the Mood for Love'' (Hong Kong), Jia Zhangke's ''Platform'' (China-Japan) and Edward Yang's ''Yi Yi'' (Taiwan).

''BLOW DRY'' Alan Rickman is a hair stylist competing in England's cutthroat National Hairdressing Championships held in Keighley, a working-class city. From the writer of ''The Full Monty.'' With Natasha Richardson, Josh Harnett and Rachel Griffiths. Sept. 22.

''CHUTNEY POPCORN'' The serious comedy by Nisha Ganatra examines the complications when an Indian-American lesbian decides to have a baby for her infertile sister. Homophobia, culture shock, single parenthood and cultural assimilation are among the themes treated lightly. Sept. 22.

''THE DANCER'' ''Flashdance'' meets ''Children of a Lesser God'' in the story of a beautiful mute dancer and the scientist who invents a device that allows her to ''talk'' through movement. Directed by Luc Besson. Sept. 22.
''30 DAYS'' A romantic comedy starring Ben Shenkman and Arija Bareikis examines the New York City dating scene. Sept. 22.

''DOUBLE PARKED'' Stephen Kinsella's film (a Slam Dance festival favorite) is the story of a meter maid (Callie Thorne) trying to earn enough to care for her sickly teenage son (Rufus Read). Sept. 22.
''THE FANTASTICKS'' The longest-running Off Broadway musical in history finally makes it to the screen, directed by Michael Ritchie. With Joey McIntyre and Jean Louisa Kelly. Sept. 22.

''THE GREAT DANCE: A HUNTER'S STORY'' The way of the life of the San, a nomadic hunting tribe in the central Kalahari, is imperiled by commercial development. Craig and Damon Foster directed the documentary. Sept. 22.

''LEFT LUGGAGE'' A young nanny (Laura Fraser) accepts a job with a Hasidic Jewish family in Antwerp, Belgium, in the early 70's and learns to accept their culture and values. With Isabella Rossellini, Maximilian Schell and Topol. Sept. 22.

''PRINCE OF CENTRAL PARK'' John Leekley directed the teary-eyed drama of a lost little boy (Frankie Nasso) fleeing an abusive foster mother who survives in New York's Central Park until his miraculous emotional rescue. With Kathleen Turner, Danny Aiello, Harvy Keitel, Cathy Moriarty and Jerry Orbach. Sept. 22.
''THE SPECIALS'' A spoof of the superhero genre, with Rob Lowe and Melissa Joan Hart. Sept. 22.
''THE TAVERN'' Walter Foote (son of the playwright Horton Foote) wrote, directed and produced this drama of two middle-aged men who pool their life savings to buy a tavern in Manhattan. Sept. 22
''TIGERLAND'' Joel Schumacher directed this ''small'' film set in a military boot camp during the Vietnam era. Sept. 22.

''UNDER SUSPICION'' Gene Hackman and Morgan Freeman go head to head in this psychological thriller set on New Year's Eve on a small Caribbean island. A remake of the 1982 French thriller ''Garde a Vue.'' Sept. 22.
''URBAN LEGENDS: THE FINAL CUT'' This sequel is set in a film school where competitors for the coveted Hitchcock Award keep getting murdered. Sept. 22.

''WOMAN ON TOP'' Penelope Cruz stars as a lusty Brazilian chef who leaves her troubled marriage and travels to San Francisco where she gets her own television cooking show. Sept. 22. A related article is on Page 73.

* ''DANCER IN THE DARK'' Lars von Trier's controversial ''musical,'' with songs by the Icelandic pop singer Bjork (who also stars), won two top awards at the Cannes Film Festival but was reviled by more than one American critic. The movie, which opens the New York Film Festival, could turn out to be the ''The Rite of Spring'' of film musicals by dividing audiences into cheering and booing sections. Set in rural America in 1964, it is the Danish director's third film in which the leading character is martyred. Bjork plays a Czech expatriate factory worker who is going blind and dreams of playing Maria von Trapp in a local production of ''The Sound of Music.'' The highly choreographed song and dance numbers, with locations as different as a railroad station and a courtroom, are her childlike fantasies. Iconoclastic, to say the least. Sept. 23. A related article is on Page 53.
''TWILIGHT: LOS ANGELES'' The chameleonlike monologuist and reporter Anna Deavere Smith brings her one-woman mosaic exploring the 1992 Los Angeles riots to the screen. Sept. 27.
''BARENAKED IN AMERICA'' Jason Priestley directed this rockumentary about the Canadian pop group Barenaked Ladies on their 1998 American tour. Sept. 29.
''BEAUTIFUL'' Minnie Driver is an ambitious beauty contestant in this comic look at the pageant world and its obsessions. Sally Field's feature directorial debut. Sept. 29.

* ''BEST IN SHOW'' Following his 1997 cult favorite, ''Waiting for Guffman,'' Christopher Guest's newest mockumentary examines the world of dog owners preparing their pets for the Mayflower Kennel Club dog show in Philadelphia. The canine names (like Rhapsody in White, a poodle nicknamed Butch) say it all. If it's only half as funny as ''Guffman,'' it will still be a winner. With Mr. Guest, Catherine O'Hara, Eugene Levy, Fred Willard and Parker Posey. Sept. 29.
''BROKEN HEARTS CLUB: A ROMANTIC COMEDY'' The personal struggles of a group of gay men in West Hollywood, lightly done. With Timothy Olyphant and Dean Cain. Sept. 29.

''CLEOPATRA'S SECOND HUSBAND'' A pair of sexy housesitters refuse to leave when the owners return home. A movie that begins as a kinky black comedy becomes an account of the husband's nervous breakdown. With Boyd Kestner, Radha Mitchell and Paul Hipp. Sept. 29.

''GIRLFIGHT'' The newly hot sport of women's boxing is the subject of Karyn Kusama's directorial debut, which won awards for best director and dramatic feature at this year's Sundance festival. Michelle Rodriguez plays this female Rocky, a tough, surly Brooklyn teenager who finds her identity in the ring. Sept. 29.
''THE PRICE OF AIR'' Drugs and angst in suburbia. Directed by Josh Evans, who stars with Michael Madsen. Sept. 29.

''REMEMBER THE TITANS'' Denzel Washington stars in the true story, set in 1971, of an African-American football coach who takes the reins when two Alexandria, Va., high schools -- one black, one white -- are forced to integrate. Will Patton is the much-loved white coach (forced to be the new coach's subordinate) with whom he forms a bond, and they unite the town. The first movie directed by Boaz Yakin since ''A Price Above Rubies.'' Sept. 29.
October

''BAMBOOZLED'' Spike Lee's edgy, satirical race comedy stars Damon Wayans as a television writer so desperate for a hit that he conceives a contemporary minstrel show -- and the network eats it up like candy. The show turns wearing blackface into a national craze. With Jada Pinkett Smith, Savion Glover and Tommy Davidson. Oct. 6.

''BOOTMEN'' A young steelworker in Newcastle, Australia, determined to break the pattern of his family's life, becomes a tap dancer. Directed by Dein Perry. With Adam Garcia. Oct. 6. A related article is on Page 69.
''BOYS LIFE 3'' This anthology of short gay-oriented films includes a directorial contribution by Barbra Streisand's son, Jason Gould. Oct. 6.
''CYBERWORLD'' This 3-D Imax extravaganza of computer-animated shorts includes appearances by characters from ''The Simpsons'' and a saucy synthetic hostess named Phig. Oct. 6.
''DIGIMON: SPACE DIGITAL MONSTER'' Japanese animated science fiction. The Digworld planet versus an Internet monster. Oct. 6.

''GET CARTER'' A remake of the 1971 British gangster film and cult favorite that starred Michael Caine has been relocated in the United States with Sylvester Stallone in the lead and Mr. Caine returning for a smaller role as a bartender. With Rachael Leigh Cook, Alan Cumming and Miranda Richardson. Oct. 6.
''LIVE NUDE GIRLS UNITE!'' A lighthearted documentary about a group of strippers who band together to create the only exotic dancers' union in the United States. Oct. 6.

''MEET THE PARENTS'' This comedy stars Ben Stiller as a mild-mannered nurse who has a disastrous first meeting with his future father-in-law (Robert De Niro). It's downhill from there. With Teri Polo and Blythe Danner. Oct. 6.

''REQUIEM FOR A DREAM'' In this bleaker-than-bleak film about drugs and drug dealing, directed by Darren Aronofsky (''Pi'') from Hubert Selby Jr.'s 1978 novel, Jared Leto is a heroin addict, Ellen Burstyn his diet-pill-popping mother, Jennifer Connelly his girlfriend and Marlon Wayans his best pal. They skid downhill into despair and delusions. Oct. 6. A related article is on Page 68.

''TWO FAMILY HOUSE'' In this low-key drama set in 1950's Staten Island, an enterprising Italian-American (Michael Rispoli) dreams of opening a nightclub on the first floor of his shabby two-family home. The problem is that the upstairs tenants won't leave. Winner of the Audience Award at the Sundance festival. Oct. 6.

''YI YI'' (''A ONE AND A TWO'') The Taiwanese filmmaker Edward Yang was named best director at the Cannes International Film Festival for this nearly three-hour multigenerational portrait of the Jian family in contemporary Taipei. A New York Film Festival selection. Oct. 6.

''ANIMAL FACTORY'' The second film of Steve Buscemi, who made an auspicious directorial debut with ''Trees Lounge,'' is a prison drama about the friendship between a drug dealer (Edward Furlong) and the gang leader (Willem Dafoe) who takes him under his wing. Oct. 13.

''BILLY ELLIOT'' A spunky 11-year-old-boy (the remarkable Jamie Bell), to the horror of his family and neighbors in a Northern England coal mining town, prefers ballet to boxing lessons. This crowd pleaser at the Cannes festival features Julie Waters as the hard-bitten dance teacher who believes in him. The movie wants to be ''Ma Vie en Rose'' meets ''The Full Monty.'' Oct. 13. A related article is on Page 69.

''BOUNCE'' Don Roos (''The Opposite of Sex'') wrote and directed this romantic drama about a hip young advertising executive (Ben Affleck) from Los Angeles who gives up his airplane seat to another traveler so he can have a one-night stand. When he learns that the plane crashed, he finds the widow (Gwyneth Paltrow) of the man who took his seat and they fall in love. Let's hope it's not ''Random Hearts'' for the younger set. Oct. 13. A related article is on Page 50.

''THE CONTENDER'' Rod Lurie's drama, which has strong advance word of mouth, stars Joan Allen as a popular senator whose nomination for vice president is thrown into doubt by a looming sex scandal. With Jeff Bridges, Christian Slater and Gary Oldman. Oct. 13.

* ''DR. T AND THE WOMEN'' Robert Altman's latest stars Richard Gere as a harried Dallas gynecologist to the rich, juggling many women in his personal and professional lives. Farrah Fawcett is his unstable wife, Kate Hudson his cheerleader daughter, Laura Dern his champagne-swilling sister-in-law and Shelley Long his doting chief nurse. Helen Hunt is an affable golf pro he meets on the links and Liv Tyler his soon-to-be-married daughter's mysterious maid of honor. Has the sound of one of Mr. Altman's classic ensemble pieces. Oct. 13.

''THE FOLLOWERS'' The relationship among three friends who want to pledge the same fraternity becomes embattled when one of them is not accepted because he is black. With Sam Trammell and Eddie T. Robinson. Oct. 13.
''JUST LOOKING'' Jason Alexander directed this movie, set in 1955 in the Bronx and Queens, about a sex-crazed 14-year-old voyeur. With Ryan Merriman, Gretchen Mol and Patti LuPone. Oct. 13.

''THE LADIES' MAN'' Another ''Saturday Night Live'' comedian hits the big screen. Tim Meadows plays a 70's-style jive-talking radio personality who dispenses the world's worst advice on matters of the heart and libido. With Will Ferrell, Tiffani-Amber Thiessen and Billy Dee Williams. Reginald Hudlin directed. Oct. 13.

''LOST SOULS'' The fact that ''Lost Souls'' has been sitting on the shelf for a year does not augur well for the directorial debut of Janusz Kaminski (Oscar-winning cinematographer) in which Winona Ryder battles the forces of evil. With Ben Chaplin and John Hurt. Oct. 13. A related article is on Page 57.

''ONE'' Tony Barbieri directed this drama about two young men sharing an apartment whose friendship deteriorates when one gets his life together and the other drifts downward. With Kane Picoy and Jason Cairns. Oct. 13.

''RATCATCHER'' Lynne Ramsay wrote and directed this British drama (acclaimed at New Directors/New Films), set in a Glasgow housing project during the mid-70's garbage strikes, about an alienated 12-year-old boy and his friends. Oct. 13.

''WHISPERS: AN ELEPHANT'S TALE'' This live comic adventure from Disney tells the true story of a baby elephant stranded in the wild, searching for its lost mother. With the voices of Angela Bassett, Joanna Lumley and Anne Archer. Oct. 13.

''BEDAZZLED'' Harold Ramis directed this remake of the Dudley Moore-Peter Cook comedy about a man (Brendan Fraser) who makes a deal with the Devil (in the gorgeous guise of Elizabeth Hurley) to fulfill his dreams of becoming rich, powerful and sexy. He's not satisfied when he still can't win the love of a co-worker (Frances O'Connor). Oct. 20. A related article is on Page 57.

''JUST ONE TIME'' Lane Janger, Joelle Carter and Guillermo Diaz star in this romantic comedy about an engaged young couple's ''deal'' to explore their sexual fantasies and the unforeseen consequences. Mr. Janger directed. Oct. 20.
''M.V.P.: MOST VALUABLE PRIMATE'' In the cutesy-poo family tradition of ''Air Bud,'' ''M.V.P.'' brings us a hockey-playing chimpanzee. Oct. 20.

''PAY IT FORWARD'' This feel-good movie, adapted from a novel by Catherine Ryan Hyde, stars Kevin Spacey as a teacher who gives his class an assignment to make the world a better place. The supermoppet Haley Joel Osment is the troubled student who dreams up the concept of ''paying forward'' by performing random acts of kindness for three strangers, each of whom must in turn do the same. High on the boy's list of priorities is fixing his teacher up with his alcoholic mother (Helen Hunt). ''As Good as It Gets'' with sugar on top? Oct. 20.
''RING OF FIRE'' Marcus Thomas is a daredevil rodeo rider, Kiefer Sutherland his older brother and Daryl Hannah the woman they both covet. Oct. 20.

''A ROOM FOR ROMEO BRASS'' Shane Meadows directed this British coming-of-age story about two 12-year-old boys and best friends -- one tough (Ben Marshall), the other sensitive (Gavin Knocks Wolley) -- in the Midlands. Oct. 20.

''THE YARDS'' This gritty New York crime drama stars two red-hot actors, Mark Wahlberg and Joaquin Phoenix, as cousins and cutthroat rivals in a corrupt family business (subway car repairs) that involves sabotage, payoffs and murder. With Charlize Theron, James Caan, Ellen Burstyn and Faye Dunaway. Not embraced at Cannes. Oct. 20.
''SOUND AND FURY'' Josh Aronson directed this documentary about the impact on one family of cochlear implants, devices that can give the deaf the ability to hear. Oct. 25.

''BOOK OF SHADOWS: BLAIR WITCH 2'' The sequel to last year's no-budget horror blockbuster was directed by the respected documentarian Joe Berlinger (''Paradise Lost: The Child Murders at Robin Hood Hills''). Two new unknowns, Jeff Donovan and Erica Leerhsen, are part of a touring party over the same turf. Opens just in time for Halloween. Oct. 27. A related article is on Page 57.
''THE BRIDGE'' Gerard Depardieu makes his directorial debut (and stars) in the story of a love affair set in the 1960's. With Carole Bouquet and Charles Berling. Oct. 27.

''GEORGE WASHINGTON'' A child's accidental death at an abandoned amusement park in a small Southern town sets his friends to soul-searching. David Gordon Green directed the cast of nonprofessional actors. A New York Film Festival selection. Oct. 27.
''THE LITTLE VAMPIRE'' In this fantasy, based on a popular children's book, Jonathan Lipnicki (''Stuart Little'') becomes friendly with a bunch of vampires. With Richard E. Grant. Oct. 27.
''LOVING JEZEBEL'' A hopeless romantic (Hill Harper) who always falls in love with women who are unavailable finds history repeating itself, but with a difference. Oct. 27.

''LUCKY NUMBERS'' In this dark comedy directed by Nora Ephron, John Travolta is a high-living television weatherman in Pennsylvania who, desperate to escape financial ruin, schemes with the station's lotto ball girl (Lisa Kudrow) to rig the state lottery drawing. Then their scheme begins to unravel. Can Ms. Ephron, the queen of fluffy romantic comedy, get even halfway heavy? With Tim Roth, Ed O'Neill and Michael Rapaport. Oct. 27.

''ONCE IN THE LIFE'' Laurence Fishburne and Titus Welliver star in this drama of two estranged brothers, both from the world of crime, who reconnect after years apart and become involved in a drug deal. Mr. Fishburne, who directed, adapted the screenplay from his original stage play ''Riff Raff.'' Oct. 27.

''STARDOM'' This Canadian film, directed by Denys Arcand and featuring Dan Aykroyd, Frank Langella, Thomas Gibson and Charles Berling, is a biting show business comedy about the meteoric rise of a model (a newcomer, Jessica Pare) from obscurity to international renown. Oct. 27.

''A TIME FOR DRUNKEN HORSES'' The Kurdish director Bahman Ghobadi (an associate of Abbas Kiarostami) directed this political drama about a poverty-stricken family in Iranian Kurdistan who sacrifice everything to try to save their youngest boy, who is in need of life-saving surgery. Oct. 27.

''VENUS BEAUTY INSTITUTE'' This serious comedy, directed by Tonie Marshall, was a hit in France, where it also swept the Cesar awards (the French Oscars). Set in and around a Parisian beauty spa, it examines the personal lives of four women. With Nathalie Baye and Audrey Tatou. Oct. 27.
''WHAT'S COOKING?'' This Thanksgiving Day mosaic looks at the troubles of four families: black, Jewish, Asian and Latino. Oct. 27. A related article is on Page 73.

''ME AND ISAAC NEWTON'' Michael Apted directed this documentary exploring the lives and careers of seven distinguished scientists who range in age from 38 to 81 and whose specialties include fields as different as robotics and cancer research.

''POLLOCK'' Ed Harris directed and stars in this film biography of the Abstract Expressionist painter Jackson Pollock. The film, the official centerpiece of the New York Film Festival, features Marcia Gay Harden as his wife, Lee Krasner; Jeffrey Tambor as the critic Clement Greenberg; and Amy Madigan as the collector Peggy Guggenheim. Val Kilmer is Willem de Kooning.
''TOO TIRED TO DIE'' With Takeshi Kaneshiro and Mira Sorvino. Wonsuk Chin directed this metaphysical drama about a young man visited by Death, who tells him he has only 12 hours to live.
November
''THE AMATI GIRLS'' With Mercedes Ruehl, Paul Sorvino and Cloris Leachman. Grown-up sisters cope with their difficult mother. Nov. 3.

''CHARLIE'S ANGELS'' The $90 million film debut of the music-video director McG resurrects one of the sillier 1970's television series. Here, the Angels -- Drew Barrymore, Cameron Diaz and Lucy Liu -- are assigned to prevent the assassination of their boss (the voice of John Forsythe) by a computer-wise madman (Tim Curry). Nov. 3. A related article is on Page 70.

''THE GOLDEN BOWL'' Secrets and lies in lavish landscapes. This film completes the Merchant Ivory trilogy of Henry James adaptations. Nick Nolte is a wealthy American art collector living in Europe and Kate Beckinsale is his adoring daughter. They are caught up in a web of deceit when she marries a charming but impoverished Italian prince (Jeremy Northam), who was once the lover of her best friend (Uma Thurman), who in turn marries her father. Nov. 3. A related article is on Page 63.

* ''THE LEGEND OF BAGGER VANCE'' Robert Redford directed this adaptation of Steven Pressfield's warm and fuzzy 1995 novel. It's about an amateur golfer and war hero (Matt Damon) who, guided by the divine intervention of his mystically connected caddie (Will Smith), takes on the pros. With Charlize Theron and Bruce McGill. ''The Natural'' goes to the links? Nov. 3.

''RED PLANET'' As Earth becomes too polluted to support life, Val Kilmer leads a team of technologists to Mars to prepare a colony. The special effects are laid on thick. With Carrie-Anne Moss, Tom Sizemore and Benjamin Bratt. Nov. 3.

''THE WEEKEND'' Brian Skeet wrote and directed the drama of eight people who gather on the anniversary of the death of a man who is related to them all -- by either blood or love. ''The Big Chill 2000''? With Brooke Shields, Gena Rowlands, D. B. Sweeney and Jared Harris. Nov. 3.
''WHAT'S COOKING?'' This Thanksgiving Day mosaic looks at the troubles of four families: black, Jewish, Asian and Latino. Oct. 27 A related article is on Page 73.

''SUZHOU RIVER'' Set in contemporary Shanghai, the Chinese director Lou Ye's melodrama about obsession is, among other things, an homage to ''Vertigo.'' Won the grand prize at the 1999 Rotterdam International Film Festival. Nov. 8.
''ANGEL'S LADIES'' A documentary about an Oregon couple who ''retire'' to Nevada to open a brothel. Nov. 10.

''LITTLE NICKY'' Adam Sandler plays the title role of Satan's shy, awkward ''good'' son. When Dad makes his two ''bad'' older brothers heirs to his throne, they go to New York, determined to establish hell on earth. Satan orders meek little Nicky and his guide (a foulmouthed dog) to follow them and restore the balance between good and evil. With Tony Lister Jr. and Rhys Ifans the baddies, Harvey Keitel as Satan and Rodney Dangerfield as Grandpa Satan. Nov. 10. A related article is on Page 57.
''MALENA'' More nostalgia from Guiseppe Tornatore (''Cinema Paradiso'') in the story of a 13-year-old Sicilian boy bewitched by a World War II widow (Monica Bellucci). Nov. 10.

''MEN OF HONOR'' This inspirational fact-based military drama stars Cuba Gooding Jr. as the Navy's fanatically determined first black diver and Robert De Niro as his Southern racist instructor, who learns a few lessons before the movie is over and becomes the diver's biggest champion. Charlize Theron is Mr. De Niro's embittered wife. Very rah-rah patriotic. Nov. 10.
''NONSTOP'' Three losers -- an inept bank robber, a convenience store clerk and a washed-up rock star -- end up chasing one another through the streets of Tokyo. Nov.10.

* ''QUILLS'' Great word of mouth precedes the release of this film (directed by Philip Kaufman) about the later years of the Marquis de Sade (Geoffrey Rush) in Charenton Asylum, where he continues to write incendiary prose while being tended by a humane Roman Catholic priest (Joaquin Phoenix). Kate Winslet is a laundress who smuggles his subversive manuscripts to his publisher. The going gets tough when a new doctor (Michael Caine) appointed by Napoleon arrives to ''cure'' him, by any means necessary, of his nasty writing habit. Nov. 10. A related article is on Page 63.

* ''YOU CAN COUNT ON ME'' Hot critical buzz (especially around the performance of Laura Linney) precedes this family drama, which won the Grand Jury Prize and Waldo Salt Screenwriting Award at Sundance. Ms. Linney and Mark Ruffalo are a sister and brother, orphaned as children, who grew up in a small upstate New York town. She's a churchgoing single mother, he's a drifter, and when he appears hoping to borrow money, they struggle to reconcile their differences. The directorial debut of the playwright Kenneth Lonergan, who wrote the screenplay. Nov. 10.

''DR. SEUSS' HOW THE GRINCH STOLE CHRISTMAS'' Ron Howard directed this holiday movie about a grouchy, bushy-eyebrowed, furry green beast with a snout (Jim Carrey buried under tons of makeup) who tries to prevent the people of Whoville from celebrating Christmas. With Molly Shannon, Christine Baranski and Bill Irwin. Nov. 17.
''LIES'' Jang Sun Woo, the bad boy of Korean cinema, blends hard-core sadomasochism with a Lolita-esque coming-of-age story. Nov. 17.
''RUGRATS IN PARIS -- THE MOVIE'' The Pickles family goes to France to work at an amusement park. Trouble awaits the wee ones. Nov. 17.

''THE SIXTH DAY'' In this futuristic thriller Arnold Schwarzenegger is a helicopter pilot who discovers he has unknowingly been cloned. With Robert Duvall, Tony Goldwyn and Michael Rapaport. Sounds awfully familiar. Has the formula worn thin? Nov. 17.

''102 DALMATIANS'' In the sequel, Cruella De Vil (Glenn Close), more overdressed than ever, teams up with an evil Parisian fur merchant (Gerard Depardieu) with a taste for spotted fur ensembles. Directed by Kevin Lima (''Tarzan''). Nov. 22.
''THE TRENCH'' The directorial debut of the novelist William Boyd remembers the Battle of the Somme in 1916, the bloodiest massacre in British Army history. Nov. 22.

''UNBREAKABLE'' Can box office lightning strike twice? This supernatural thriller reunites M. Night Shyamalan, the creator of ''The Sixth Sense,'' with its star, Bruce Willis, for a drama in which Mr. Willis is the sole survivor of a train crash outside Philadelphia. With Samuel L. Jackson, Robin Wright Penn and Spencer Treat Clark. Along with the chills, Mr. Shyamalan likes to pile on the spiritual suds, so expect to have some tears jerked. Nov. 22.
''TWO NINAS'' Two beautiful women fall in love with the unluckiest guy in the world. With Amanda Peet, Cara Buono and Ron Livingston.

''BOESMAN AND LENA'' In the South African playwright Athol Fugard's highly regarded drama, an impoverished, embattled couple forced to live in the mud flats of Cape Town create a makeshift shelter to get them through the night. A stranger appears and changes their lives. The screen adaptation, directed by John Berry, a blacklisted Hollywood screenwriter who died last year at the age of 82, stars Danny Glover and Angela Bassett and is a selection of the New York Film Festival.
''CHERRY FALLS'' Set in a small Virginia own, this horror flick stars Brittany Murphy as a high school student stalking a serial killer whose victims are all virgins. With Jay Mohr.

''IN THE MOOD FOR LOVE'' Tony Leung Chiu-wai was named best actor at Cannes for this film, directed by Wong Kar-wai, a love story set in Hong Kong's Shanghai community in the 1960's. He and Maggie Cheung are neighbors who, upon discovering their spouses are having an affair, embark on their own relationship. A selection of the New York Film Festival.
''LOCKDOWN'' Richard T. Jones stars as a young man who is arrested and thrown in jail on the way to a celebration for his having won a college swimming scholarship.

''SIGNS AND WONDERS'' Politics and psychic premonitions complicate the lives of a Greek-American expatriate family living in Athens; directed by Jonathan Nossiter (''Sunday''), with Stellan Skarsgard, Charlotte Rampling and Deborah Kara Unger.

''SIMON MAGUS'' Noah Taylor is a boy in a 19th-century European village who escapes on a newly constructed railroad after being tormented by villagers who believe he is possessed by the Devil. The directorial debut of Ben Hopkins aspires to be a Tim Burton-Terry Gilliam-like phantasmagoria. A related article is on Page 57.
''SPRING FORWARD'' Liev Schreiber and Ned Beatty are an ex-convict in a small rural Connecticut town and the much-older boss from the Parks and Recreation Department who takes a chance and hires him.
December
''HILLBROW KIDS'' Michael Hammon and Jacqueline Gorgen directed this documentary about Johannesburg's homeless children. Dec. 6.
''THE ART OF AMALIA'' Bruno de Almeida directed this documentary about the Portuguese fado singer, Amalia Rodrigues. Dec. 8.

* ''CROUCHING TIGER, HIDDEN DRAGON'' Ang Lee's gorgeous Hong Kong-style action fantasy (with subtitles) was one of the biggest hits of the Cannes International Film Festival. Set in ancient China but contemporary in spirit, the movie stars Chow Yun Fat as a wise martial arts master who does battle with a fierce young female fighter (the exquisite Zhang Ziyi) after she steals his legendary sword. The spectacular dueling sequences find the combatants sailing over rooftops and hanging from the tops of trees. The epic fable also encompasses two star-crossed romances. The martial arts genre reaches a new level of sophistication. Dec. 8.

''SONGCATCHER'' Janet McTeer is a musicologist who travels to the Appalachians in 1907 and discovers a world of early American folk music and the culture that has kept it alive. With Jane Addams, Aidan Quinn and Pat Carroll. Cameo performances by Iris DeMent, Hazel Dickens and Taj Mahal. A hit at Sundance. Dec. 8.

''VERTCAL LIMIT'' Chris O'Donnell is a mountaineer who has given up the sport when he learns his younger sister (Robin Tunney) and her summit team are trapped near the top of K2, the world's second highest mountain. Dec. 8.

* ''CHOCOLAT'' Glowing word of mouth precedes the newest film from Lasse Hallstrom (''The Cider House Rules''). In this surreally tinged fable, set in 1959, Juliette Binoche is a mysterious single mother who appears and scandalizes a straitlaced French village by opening a chocolate shop (whose treats are irresistible) across the square from a church. Johnny Depp is another outsider who appears and joins forces with her to liberate the town from domination by its prudish self-appointed leader (Alfred Molina). A Gallic ''Babette's Feast''? Dec. 15. A related article is on Page 73.

''THE EMPEROR'S NEW GROOVE'' The newest animated comedy from Disney is a buddy movie set in South America and tells of an arrogant young emperor who is turned into a llama but finds his humanity after teaming up with a friendly peasant. With the voices of David Spade, Eartha Kitt and John Goodman. God forbid it should resemble that other animated buddy movie ''The Road to El Dorado.'' Dec. 15.

''FAMILY MAN'' In the newest example of a what-if genre that echoes ''It's a Wonderful Life'' and ''Peggy Sue Got Married,'' Nicolas Cage is a Wall Street playboy who discovers how his life would have turned out had he married the college sweetheart (Tea Leoni) he dumped to pursue his career. Brett Ratner (''Rush Hour'') directed this sentimental romantic comedy. Dec. 15.

''THE GIFT'' In this Southern Gothic thriller, written by Billy Bob Thornton and Tim Epperson, Cate Blanchett is a widowed mother with psychic gifts in Brixton, Ga. As her visions begin to reveal the town's darker secrets, she finds herself in danger, especially after the body of a drowned young woman is discovered. Sam Raimi directed. With Hilary Swank as an abused wife and Keanu Reeves as her husband, the town bully. Greg Kinnear is a school principal. Dec. 15.

''WHAT WOMEN WANT'' In this sexy comedy, directed by Nancy Meyers (''Parent Trap''), Mel Gibson is a womanizing Chicago advertising executive who after a freak electrical accident discovers he can read women's minds. Helen Hunt is his difficult new boss on whom he tests his new skill -- while also falling in love with her. With Marisa Tomei and Lauren Holly. Dec. 15.
''BUT FOREVER IN MY MIND'' The 1968 student protests in Italy are remembered in Gabriele Muccino's lighthearted comedy. Dec. 20.
''THIRTEEN DAYS'' The 1962 Cuban missile crisis is reimagined with the Canadian actor Bruce Greenwood as John F. Kennedy and Kevin Costner as Kenny O'Donnell, a presidential aide. Dec. 20.

* ''CASTAWAY'' If there's such a thing as a sure bet in Hollywood, Robert Zemeckis's film has got to be it. America's favorite Everyman, Tom Hanks, plays a FedEx worker, presumed dead when his plane crashes in the Pacific, surviving on a desert island. The star shed 50 pounds to play this contemporary Robinson Crusoe, whose struggle to stay alive is harrowing. Think ''Survivor'' meets ''Forrest Gump'' but heavier. Helen Hunt is the girlfriend left behind who assumes he is dead. Dec. 22

''ENEMY AT THE GATES'' The Battle of Stalingrad, a turning point of World War II, is the setting for this true story of the conflict between a Russian sniper (Jude Law) and the German officer (Ed Harris) dispatched to kill him. Directed by Jean-Jacques Annaud (''Seven Years in Tibet''). With Joseph Fiennes and Rachel Weisz. Dec. 22.

* ''O BROTHER, WHERE ART THOU?'' George Clooney, John Turturro and Tim Blake Nelson play escaped prisoners from a chain gang in the Depression-era South in the Coen brothers' homage to Preston Sturges's ''Sullivan's Travels.'' The story is also (very loosely) based on Homer's ''Odyssey.'' The quirky film, which was well received at Cannes, should test Mr. Clooney's box office clout after ''The Perfect Storm.'' Dec. 22.

''STATE AND MAIN'' Life in a sleepy Vermont town is disrupted by the arrival of a Hollywood film crew. David Mamet wrote and directed this scabrous comedy about movie people and their egos. William H. Macy is the fictional director, Alec Baldwin and Sarah Jessica Parker the stars, and Philip Seymour Hoffman the screenwriter. Dec. 22. A related article is on Page 53.

''TRAFFIC'' Steven Soderbergh (a super-hot director after ''Erin Brockovich'') directed this thriller (adapted from a British mini-series) about the international drug trade, which entwines several interrelated dramas. Michael Douglas is the president's new anti-drug czar, Steven Bauer and Catherine Zeta-Jones a drug baron and his wife, Benicio Del Toro a Mexican policeman, and Don Cheadle and Luiz Guzman federal agents. With Dennis Quaid, Benajmin Bratt, Albert Finney and Amy Irving. Dec. 22.
''WES CRAVEN PRESENTS: DRACULA 2000'' Patrick Lussier directed this millennial update of an old favorite, complete with Goth fashions and high-tech silver bullets. Dec. 22.

* ''ALL THE PRETTY HORSES'' Billy Bob Thornton directed Matt Damon and Henry Thomas in the screen version of Cormac McCarthy's much-loved western novel, set in the 1940's. Two young cowboys in search of adventure end up working on a horse ranch, where Mr. Damon falls in love with the owner's daughter (Penelope Cruz). Dec. 25.

''AN EVERLASTING PIECE'' Barry Levinson directed and Barry McEvoy wrote and stars in this comedy about a wig salesman in Belfast in the 1980's. Two barbers -- one Catholic, the other Protestant -- form an alliance to corner the toupee market in Northern Ireland. With Brian F. O'Byrne, Anna Friel and Billy Connolly. Dec. 25.

''MOULIN ROUGE'' Baz Luhrmann, who reinvented Shakespeare for the MTV generation with ''Romeo and Juliet,'' tries to salvage the movie musical with this trippy, beat-driven fantasy of the world of Toulouse-Lautrec. Ewan McGregor is a rebellious young poet who goes boho with a vengeance and moves to Montmartre. Nicole Kidman is the Moulin Rouge's star courtesan, and John Leguizamo is Toulouse-Lautrec. Traditionalists will no doubt be outraged at the use of contemporary music in a period setting. Dec. 25 .
''SLACKERS'' Three buddies are happily scamming their way through college when the campus geek catches on to their schemes. Dec. 25

''VATEL'' Roland Joffe directed this lavish 17th-century costume drama about Louis XIV's caterer (Gerard Depardieu), who falls in love with the king's favorite courtesan (Uma Thurman). The screenplay is by Jeanne LaBrune and Tom Stoppard. With Tim Roth, Timothy Spall and Julian Sands. Dec. 25. A related article is Page 73.

''SHADOW OF THE VAMPIRE'' This spoof of moviemaking takes us back to the set of the 1922 silent film classic ''Nosferatu,'' where John Malkovich is the director, F. W. Murnau. Willem Dafoe has drawn advance buzz for his portrayal of the first actor to play a vampire on the screen. The directorial debut of E. Elias Merhige. Dec. 29. A related article is on Page 57.
''BUYING THE COW'' A commitment-phobe (Jerry O'Connell) is given a deadline to propose to his girlfriend.
''THE CLAIM'' Sarah Polley and Wes Bentley star in Michael Winterbottom's film version of Thomas Hardy's ''Mayor of Casterbridge.''

''FINDING FORRESTER'' Sean Connery is a reclusive author who mentors a gifted teenage basketball player and writer (the newcomer Robert Brown) and helps him choose between sports and literature. With F. Murray Abraham (as a meddlesome teacher) and Anna Paquin. Gus Van Sant directed. If it lives up to its promise, it might almost be ''Good Will Hunting: The Sequel.''

''MISS CONGENIALITY'' Sandra Bullock produced and stars in this wacky comedy about an untalented, tomboyish F.B.I. agent posing as a beauty contestant to foil a bomb threat. Directed by Donald Petrie (''Grumpy Old Men''). With Michael Caine, Benjamin Bratt and William Shatner.

''PROOF OF LIFE'' David Morse is a civil engineer abducted in South America while building a dam and Russell Crowe is a professional hostage negotiator brought in to save his life. Emotional complications set in when the negotiator and the victim's wife (Meg Ryan) fall in love. Taylor Hackford directed.
January
''KNOCKAROUND GUYS'' A mobster's sons in a small town in Montana steal from their elders. Starring John Malkovich, Dennis Hopper and Vin Diesel. Directed by David Levien and Brian Koppelman. Jan. 12.
''FAITHLESS'' Ingmar Bergman wrote the script and Liv Ullman directed this evisceration of modern marriage and adultery. A selection of the New York Film Festival. Jan. 26.
''CHUNHYANG'' Im Kwon-taek directed the 18th-century Korean epic that is a selection of the New York Film Festival.
February

''HANNIBAL'' The sequel to ''Silence of the Lambs,'' directed by Ridley Scott, continues the story of Hannibal Lecter (Anthony Hopkins) seven years after F.B.I. agent Clarice Starling (Julianne Moore) interviewed him in a hospital for the criminally insane. One of his victims who nearly died vows revenge and uses Clarice as bait. With Ray Liotta.
''ONE NIGHT AT MCCOOL'S'' With Liv Tyler, Matt Dillon, Paul Reiser, John Goodman. Directed by Harald Zwart.
''RULES OF ATTRACTION'' With Samantha Mathis and Gretchen Mol.
March

''TOWN AND COUNTRY'' Starring Warren Beatty, Diane Keaton, Andie MacDowell, Goldie Hawn. Directed by Peter Chelsom. The long delayed, reputedly troubled romantic comedy finally has a tentative opening date: March 16.
April
''PLUTO NASH'' Starring Eddie Murphy. Directed by Ron Underwood. April 6.
''CHAMPS'' Starring Sylvester Stallone. Directed by Renny Harlin. April 27.
''KINGDOM COME'' With Whoopi Goldberg, Jada Pinkett Smith and LL Cool J. Directed by Doug McHenry.
''WHAT'S THE WORST THAT CAN HAPPEN?'' Starring Martin Lawrence and Danny DeVito.

''BRIDGET JONES' DIARY'' Renee Zellweger, Hugh Grant and Colin Firth. Sharon Maguire directed the screen adaptation of the English novel that some considered a bellwether of modern dating manners. A related article is on Page 50.
May
''THE MUMMY RETURNS'' The sequel to the horror comedy blockbuster brings back Brendan Fraser, Rachel Weisz and John Hannah, and features the wrestling superstar Dwayne (The Rock) Johnson. May 11.

''PEARL HARBOR'' Starring Cuba Gooding Jr., Ben Affleck, Josh Harnett, James King. The exploits of two young pilots in the U.S. Army Air Corps who grew up together span three continents and much of World War II. Events include the attack on Pearl Harbor and the bombing of Tokyo. Directed by Michael Bay. May 25. A related article is on Page 50.
''SHREK'' Animated with the voices of Mike Myers, Eddie Murphy, John Lithgow, Linda Hunt and Cameron Diaz.

''A.I.'' Starring Jude Law and Haley Joel Osment. Steven Spielberg directed this science fiction ''collaboration'' with Stanley Kubrick from one of the late director's unproduced screenplays. June 29.

''ANNIVERSARY'' With Jennifer Jason Leigh and Alan Cumming.
''THE JOHNSON FIVE'' Adam Sandler's summer biggie.
''SWORDFISH'' Starring John Travolta.
July ''ALI'' Will Smith takes on what may be his most challenging role playing the boxing legend Muhammad Ali.

''FINAL FANTASY'' The futuristic action-adventure film directed by Hironobu Sakaguchi features computer-generated animated photo-realistic figures and the voices of Alec Baldwin, Ving Rhames and Donald Sutherland, among others.
''PLANET OF THE APES'' Tim Burton directed the re-make of the 1968 Charlton Heston science fiction classic.
''WINDTALKERS'' Starring Nicolas Cage and Adam Beach. Directed by John Woo. Action.
August
''BANDITS'' Starring Bruce Willis, Billy Bob Thornton and Cate Blanchett. Directed by Barry Levinson. Formerly called ''The Outlaws.''
''SPIDERMAN'' Tobey Maguire plays the title role of the comic book hero with superhuman powers and spider-like physical tenacity.

''THE ADVENTURES OF JOE DIRT'' A belligerent 8-year-old boy abandoned by his parents in Grand Central Station and now grown up tells his spellbinding life story on the radio. With David Spade.
''BASIC INSTINCT 2'' Starring Sharon Stone. The witch is back.
''DOCTOR DOOLITTLE 2'' The inevitable sequel starring Eddie Murphy.
''FROM HELL'' Starring Johnny Depp, Ian Holm and Heather Graham. Directed by Albert and Allen Hughes.
''JURASSIC PARK 3'' Steven Spielberg didn't direct (Joe Johnston did), but at least Sam Neill is back for more dinosaurian mayhem.
''THE SCORE'' Starring Robert De Niro, Edward Norton, Marlon Brando and Angela Bassett. Directed by Frank Oz.

''THE TAILOR OF PANAMA'' In the screen adaptation of John le Carre's novel, Pierce Brosnan is a charming but ruthless British spy and Geoffrey Rush is a Cockney ex-convict turned high-society tailor in Panama City. He is also a storyteller, one of whose yarns inadvertently sets off an ominous chain of events. This thriller, which has black comedy touches, was directed by John Boorman. With Jamie Lee Curtis.
''THE WEDDING PLANNER'' Jennifer Lopez is a wedding planner whose workaholism prevents her from finding Mr. Right. Directed by Adam Shankman. With Matthew McConaughey.
